node.title: Postal Service reform bill heads to Senate after bipartisan House vote
node.description: "It is my intention for the Senate to quickly take up and pass this bipartisan, bicameral postal reform bill," Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said.

node.title: How to claim child credit money on your taxes this year
node.description: Although the enhanced payments ended in December, families who didn't get their money last year can still claim it.

node.title: U.S. replaces Trump mission statement that cut "nation of immigrants" label
node.description: The Biden administration's new mission statement calls the U.S. "a nation of welcome and possibility."

node.title: Malala Yousafzai joins outcry over "horrifying" hijab bans in India
node.description: A state-run college in Karnataka state barred a group of Muslim students from class, sparking a wave of protests and rekindling India's deep-rooted religious tension.

node.title: Super Bowl menu ideas and recipes
node.description: From burgers, hot dogs, tacos, BBQ and wings, to salsas and cocktails, here are some tempting recipes from top chefs, cookbook authors and restaurateurs to go with watching the Big Game!

node.title: Met Museum to Renovate Its Ancient Near East and Cypriot Galleries
node.description: Construction for the $40 million project is expected to start next year and finish in 2025.

node.title: ‘It Was a Crusade’: Karen Brooks Hopkins Revisits Her BAM Tenure
node.description: In a new memoir, the former president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music reflects on some of the organization’s most memorable stagings and artists.

node.title: How to Watch Nathan Chen Chase Gold in Men’s Figure Skating
node.description: If Chen can maintain his lead in the free skate, he’ll win an Olympic gold medal. His rival, Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, is looking for a comeback.

node.title: For Drew Carey, Valentine's Day a painful reminder of ex-fiancée's death
node.description: "The Price Is Right" host and Harwick's close friends open up about their love and loss of the popular Hollywood therapist.

node.title: Florida's controversial "Don't Say Gay" school bill moves forward
node.description: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis said he doesn't support "injecting these concepts about choosing your gender" at schools.

node.title: NATO and Russia hold war games amid talks to deescalate Ukraine crisis
node.description: The U.S. and its NATO partners are still negotiating with Russia amid military buildups by both sides, but military preparations are not based on best-case scenarios.

node.title: Internet guru Tim O'Reilly on Web3: "Get ready for the crash"
node.description: Tech luminary who coined the term "Web 2.0" on cryptocurrency, NFTs and blockchain: "It's kind of like a pyramid scheme."

node.title: Moose attacks Iditarod sled team, injuring 4 dogs: "I ran for my life"
node.description: The attack didn't end even after Bridgett Watkins emptied her gun into the animal, she said.

node.title: Mikaela Shiffrin out early in second Olympic race in a row
node.description: Announcers called it "near the top of the list for all-time Olympic disappointments."

node.title: Skater found dead 37 feet underwater after ice breaks at reservoir
node.description: The two who didn't fall helped the others but couldn't find the man who was the farthest from the group, the Sierra County Sheriff's Office said.

node.title: America's allies in Syria accuse Turkey of giving ISIS a "safe zone"
node.description: The rebel Syrian Democratic Forces have been America's go-to ally in the fight against ISIS, but another ISIS leader's death near Turkey has them asking difficult questions.

node.title: Book Banning Is About the Illusion of Parental Control
node.description: If students really want to read “Maus,” they’ll find a way.

node.title: Tonga extends its lockdown in the capital as Covid cases rise.
node.description: The island nation barely saw the coronavirus in the first two years of the pandemic. But after a volcanic eruption, an outbreak among visiting aid workers has pushed up its caseload.

node.title: Mom, son texted about gun before Michigan mass school shooting
node.description: The case is highly unusual because parents are rarely held criminally responsible for teens accused in mass school shootings.

node.title: Unionization efforts gain momentum on Capitol Hill
node.description: A new resolution marks the first step in what could be a lengthy process for staffers.

node.title: North Korea expert Sue Mi Terry on future of Kim Jong un regime
node.description: Former senior CIA analyst Sue Mi Terry joins host Michael Morell to discuss North Korea's spate of missile tests this year.

node.title: Lower vaccine rates for tamariki Māori 'nothing to do with attitude' - paediatrician
node.description: Three weeks into the rollout of the paediatric Covid-19 vaccine, 42 percent of those aged five to 11 have had their first dose.

node.title: How the ‘Garlic Girls’ Overcame Abuse to Return to the Olympics
node.description: The South Korean curling team helped revive a painful discussion about the mistreatment of athletes in their country, leading the way for others to come forward.

node.title: U.S. wins its first Beijing Olympics gold
node.description: Lindsey Jacobellis took snowboardcross honors 16 years after blowing a huge lead in the same event. This time, she provided a lift for a Team USA that's been mostly underwhelming so far.

node.title: Womad, Homegrown, Auckland Arts Festival events cancelled due to Omicron threat
node.description: The Womad and Homegrown music festivals, as well as dozens of events at the Auckland Arts Festival, are the latest cultural victims of Omicron's impact on New Zealand.

node.title: Trucker protests threatening U.S.-Canada border trade
node.description: COVID-related demonstrations have expanded beyond Ottawa and mostly blocked the busiest U.S.-Canada border crossing. They're also sparking political divisions in Canada.

node.title: Libyan PM says he will defy parliament move to replace him
node.description: Libya's interim prime minister says he will defy a planned vote in parliament to replace him on Thursday, raising the prospect of two rival governments running in parallel.

node.title: Night cull at Auckland park postponed so domestic rabbits can be rounded up
node.description: Auckland Council is pressing pause on a plan to cull wild rabbits in Western Springs Park so domestic bunnies that have been dumped there can be rescued. Audio

node.title: Vector plans Auckland power outages to clear maintenance pile-up
node.description: As Auckland swelters in high humidity, lines company Vector says it has a series of power outages planned to complete a backlog of maintenance work.

node.title: ASB blames new credit act for refusing some loan applications
node.description: ASB Bank wants rapid changes to the "prescriptive" new rules of the Credit Contracts and Consumer Finance Act.
